questions.question: A patient presents with sudden diminution of vision, difficulty looking towards the light, and circumcorneal congestion with a hypopyon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: acute anterior uveitis. The presence of a hypopyon is often seen in conditions like Behcet disease, which can typically cause non-granulomatous anterior uveitis. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C do not present with a hypopyon.

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with blurred vision, photophobia, and mild ocular pain. Examination reveals aqueous flares and keratic precipitates in the anterior chamber. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Iridocyclitis Explanation: Type of Uveitis Signs Anterior (Option D) Granulomatous iridocyclitis , iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs, anterior chamber cells and flare, posterior synechiae Intermediate (Option A) Vitreous cells, snowball opacities, snowbanking Posterior (Option B) Choroidal and retinal granulomas, cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with candle wax droppings appearance Peripheral Multifocal Chorioretinitis Small, punched-out atrophic spots, highly suggestive of sarcoidosis Uveoparotid Fever (Heerfordt’s Syndrome) Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, painful parotid gland enlargement, cranial nerve palsies, skin rashes, fever, malaise Toxoplasma uveitis (Option C): Definitive host: Cat; Intermediate host: Human Ocular features: granulomatous or non-granulomatous uveitis Primarily it is posterior uveitis and spreads to anterior Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, page 443, 450-51

questions.question: Iritis is least associated with all of the following diseases:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Explanation: Iritis , also known as Anterior uveitis , is an inflammatory condition of the eye, including the iris and ciliary body. Although SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, iritis is less commonly seen in SLE compared to the other conditions listed. It more often causes other ocular manifestations, like dry eyes or retinal changes . Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Iritis (Anterior Uveitis) Infectious Causes : Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Tuberculosis (TB) Syphilis Leprosy Non-Infectious Causes : With Systemic Association : Sarcoidosis Behçet's Disease (Option B ruled out) HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis Psoriatic Arthropathy (Option C ruled out) Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) > Crohn's Disease (Option D ruled out) Without Systemic Association : Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues Masquerade Syndromes : Definition : Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature. Neoplastic Masquerades : Lymphomas Anterior Segment Melanoma Retinoblastoma Metastasis Non-Neoplastic Masquerades : Intraocular Foreign Body Old Retinal Detachment Pigment Dispersion Syndrome Coats' Disease Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology 9th ed., Page 424

questions.question: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image?
questions.explanation: history of trauma, along with the finding of white blood cells in the anterior chamber , the most likely diagnosis is hypopyon , which often results from infection or severe inflammation following eye trauma. Fungal keratitis is a common cause of corneal ulcers following eye trauma, especially when the injury is caused by vegetative matter (such as plant material or dirt). This type of trauma provides an entry point for fungal spores . The classic signs and symptoms of fungal keratitis include: Corneal ulcer with satellite lesions (smaller ulcers surrounding the main ulcer). Hypopyon (accumulation of white blood cells in the anterior chamber of the eye). Mild pain , photophobia , and redness . The history of vegetative matter as the cause of trauma is a significant clue, as fungi are commonly found in plant material. Keratomycosis Clinical Features Pain & Foreign Body Sensation Watering of the eye Photophobia Blurred Vision Redness. Examination Findings Corneal Ulcer : Greyish-white, dry-looking with elevated, rolled-out margins. Pigmented Ulcer : Brownish appearance, possible with dematiaceous fungi. Feathery Extensions : Delicate, finger-like projections into the surrounding stroma. Sterile Immune Ring : Yellow line of demarcation where fungal antigen and host antibodies meet. Satellite Lesions : Multiple small lesions around the main ulcer. Hypopyon : Large, non-sterile, even with a small ulcer. Endothelial Plaque : Located under the stromal lesion, made of fibrin and leucocytes. Corneal Vascularization : Typically absent in pure fungal ulcers. Perforation : Rare but possible. Investigations Corneal Scraping : Performed under topical anaesthesia for microbiological examination. Wet KOH Mount : Reveals filamentous fungi (branched, septate hyphae) or non-filamentous

questions.question: Iritis is not seen in: Rheumatoid arthritis SLE Bechet’s disease Psoriatic arthritis Ulcerative colitis
questions.explanation: 3 ruled out): Characterized by recurrent uveitis, including iritis, genital involvement and oral involvement. Psoriatic arthritis (Statement 4 ruled out): A seronegative spondyloarthropathy frequently associated with anterior uveitis including iritis, urethritis and arthritis. Ulcerative colitis (Statement 5 ruled out): Iritis is common in inflammatory bowel disease, as it shares a systemic inflammatory pathway. Rheumatoid arthritis: Iritis is rarely seen in adult-onset rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is more commonly associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), especially in ANA-positive cases. SLE: Systemic lupus erythematosus typically affects other ocular tissues, such as the retina and optic nerve, rather than causing iritis. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2791, 2793, 2794 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 1028, 1030 Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, Edition 10th- Page 66, 67, 68, 104.

questions.question: A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, redness, pain in the left eye, and joint pain. Upon examination keratic precipitates and aqueous cells were observed. Which of the following major histocompatibility complex is be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: redness, pain ,and keratic precipitates are suggestive of anterior uveitis. Patients with acute anterior uveitis with joint pain is suggestive of arthritis associated with uveitis. The disease affects young males who are positive for HLA B27. Among patients with ankylosing spondylitis, 90% of them belong to the HLA-B27 antigenic group. Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease Definition Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine) . Etiology Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27 ) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS. Pathophysiology Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis). Clinical Features Musculoskeletal Symptoms: Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity) Limited spinal mobility Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia) Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees) Extra-articular Symptoms: Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia) Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD Diagnosis Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria: Clinical Criteria: Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest) Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes) Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex) Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4) Radiological Features: Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint Juxta-articular sclerosis Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes Squaring of vertebrae Bamboo spine Trolley track sign Dagger sign Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae) MRI: Early detection of inflammation Clinical Tests: For Sacroiliitis: Gaenslen’s test Patrick/FABER test Figure of 4 test Pump handle test For Lumbar Spine: Schober/ Modified Schober test Laboratory Tests HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases) ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal Differential Diagnosis Mechanical low back pain Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis) Degenerative disc disease Fibromyalgia Treatment Non-Pharmacological: Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises) Patient education on disease and exercise importance Pharmacological: NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness) TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases) IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab) Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis) Corticosteroids (short-term flare control) Surgical: Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement) Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures) Complications Spinal fractures (minimal trauma) Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects) Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk HLA B51 (Option B) It is associated with Behcet's syndrome with anterior uveitis. Behcet's syndrome is characterized by bilateral recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions. HLA B47 (Option C) Is associated with congenital adrenal hyperplasia due

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient with a penetrating injury to the left eye was treated with corneoscleral suturing. Two months later, he returned with complaints of reduced near vision, pain, redness, and sensitivity to light in his right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed nodules in the fundus. Which part of the eye is affected?
questions.explanation: and subsequent reduced near vision, pain, redness, and photophobia along with nodules on fundus i.e., Dalen-Fuchs nodules are suggestive of Sympathetic ophthalmitis. Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) Definition Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis (Option A) occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma Etiology and pathogenesis Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye). T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen. Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body. Histopathology Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid. Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin. Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome) Clinical features The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable. The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom) Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous Investigations Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling. As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH. B-scan ultrasonography : Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment Treatment Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which medication can be administered to a patient diagnosed with acute anterior uveitis, presenting with symptoms of photophobia and blurred vision?
questions.explanation: Treatment of Choice ): Prednisolone : Commonly used for reducing inflammation. Loteprednol : Less potential for increasing intraocular pressure. Cycloplegics (Topical): Rest the ciliary muscles to relieve pain. Prevent and break posterior synechiae (adhesions of the iris to the lens). Improve blood supply, leading to better healing. Eg.: Atropine . Non-Steroidal Treatment : Voclosporin: Part of the Luminate program, used as a non-steroidal option. For Chronic or Vision-Threatening Uveitis : Monoclonal Antibodies : Adalimumab : TNF-alpha inhibitor, used for severe or chronic cases. Infliximab : TNF-alpha inhibitor. Interferon Alpha : An option for severe cases, helps modulate the immune response. Incorrect Options: Moxifloxacin (Option A) is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections. Acetazolamide (Option C) is a medication primarily used to treat glaucoma by reducing the production of aqueous humor and lowering intraocular pressure. Methotrexate (Option D) is an immunosuppressive medication commonly used in the treatment of various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions. It may be prescribed for severe or chronic cases of uveitis that do not respond to other treatments. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 424, 430-33

questions.question: What is the specific sign that is pathognomonic for acute anterior uveitis among the options provided?
questions.explanation: type of uveitis affecting the anterior segment of the eye. Clinical Features : Pain Redness Photophobia (sensitivity to light) Blepharospasm (involuntary blinking) Serous discharge Blurring and diminished vision Examination Findings : Keratic Precipitates (KPs) (Option B) : Non-Granulomatous : Fine, grey deposits; composed of lymphocytes Granulomatous : Large, greasy-looking deposits known as "mutton fat KPs"; composed of macrophages Location : Typically found in the lower cornea due to convection currents in aqueous humor; this area is known as Arlt's triangle Aqueous Cells : Indicator of active inflammation Aqueous Flare : Haziness in the anterior chamber due to leakage of proteins from inflamed tissues Muddy Iris : Edema in the iris caused by protein leakage Miosis : Constricted pupil due to toxins released from inflamed tissue Nodules on the Iris : Koeppe's Nodules : At the pupillary border; seen in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous uveitis Busacca Nodules : At the b ase of the iris; seen in granulomatous uveitis Complications : (Findings) Posterior Synechiae : Iris adheres to the lens; may lead to festooned-shaped pupil Secclusio Pupil/Ring Synechiae : Adhesion along the entire pupillary border; can lead to Iris Bombe and peripheral anterior synechiae, causing angle closure glaucoma Occlusio Pupil : Covers the whole surface of the lens Cyclitic Membrane Rubeosis Iridis : New vessel formation on the iris Incorrect Options: Aqueous flare (Option A) refers to the presence of protein and inflammatory cells in the aqueous humor, which may be seen in anterior uveitis. Festooned pupil (Option C) is a characteristic feature of posterior synechiae in chronic uveitis. Bussaca’s nodules (Option D) are larger, granulomatous nodules that are seen in conditions like chronic anterior uveitis, especially in sarcoidosis or tuberculosis.

questions.question: On ophthalmologic examination, the presence of Koeppe's nodules is observed in a patient diagnosed with sarcoidosis. In which area of the eye are these nodules typically observed?
questions.explanation: the iris observed in granulomatous uveitis like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, Vogt-Kanayagi-Harada’s disease, and sympathetic ophthalmitis . They are typically located at the pupillary margin, which is the border between the iris and the pupil. These nodules are composed of collections of inflammatory cells. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Koeppe’s nodules are present at the pupillary margin of the iris. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which eye condition is commonly associated with sarcoidosis ?
questions.explanation: including the eyes. Anterior uveitis, characterized by inflammation of the anterior chamber of the eye, is a common ocular manifestation of sarcoidosis. Other Ocular Features of Sarcoidosis. Sarcoid nodules on the sclera or episclera Interstitial keratitis Band-shaped keratopathy because of hypercalcemia. Candle wax dripping: Segmental or nodular periphlebitis. Lander's sign: Pre-retinal nodules. Heerfordt syndrome: Sarcoidosis with uveo-parotitis. Lofgren syndrome: Sarcoidosis with anterior uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, erythema nodosum. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These ocular features are not associated with sarcoidosis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is not an ocular manifestation of dengue?
questions.explanation: dengue fever. Incorrect Options : Option B - Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a common ocular manifestation seen in dengue fever. It is characterized by the presence of bright red patches or spots on the white part of the eye (conjunctiva). Option C - Uveitis: Uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye, can occur in dengue fever. Uveitis can present with symptoms such as eye pain, redness, sensitivity to light, and blurred vision. Option D - Retinal hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage can occur in dengue fever, particularly in severe cases or in the presence of associated complications like dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) or dengue shock syndrome (DSS). Reference: Prepladder Notes
